newsitem.title: UKRAINE: Ukraine '96 refined sugar output seen at 3.3 mln T.
newsitem.headline: Ukraine '96 refined sugar output seen at 3.3 mln T.

text.p: Ukraine's refined sugar output will reach 3.3 million tonnes, including 2.8 tonnes from this year's sugar beet harvest and 561,000 tonnes from raw imports, said a top official from the state sugar concern UkrSukor on Thursday.

"We forecast that we will sell 1.8 million tonnes on the domestic market and the rest, 1.5 million tonnes, may be exported to our traditional buyers in neighbouring countries," deputy head Olexander Bohatarenyk told Reuters.
Bohatarenyk said that Ukraine's 191 sugar refineries had so far produced 2.1 million tonnes of refined sugar and expected to refine 2.8 million tonnes from sugarbeet this year.
"Since the beginning of the year we also produced 561,000 tonnes of refined sugar from imported cane or raw sugar."
He said that 58 refineries have finished work and processed 17.4 million tonnes of sugar beets, down from last year's levels of 24.5 million tonnes at this time.
Valentyn Tymoshenko, deputy head of the Agriculture Ministry's crop department, said the sugar beet harvest was nearly finished.
"The campaign is over with 23.9 million tonnes gathered, but private farmers may add a bit more," Tymoshenko said.
Bohatarenyk said a drop in sugar prices to 600 hryvnia ($333) on the domestic market could result in the closure of many of the ageing refineries next year.
"It costs each refinery 1,200 hryvnia to make a tonne of sugar. That's the real price," he said. "The more sugar we produce, the worse it is for producers."
Ukraine's market is glutted with sugar left over from last year, when average prices were $450-460 per tonne. Many refinery workers are being paid with sugar.
He said Ukraine was most interested in exporting sugar to ease pressures on the domestic market.
But its traditional buyer, Russia, imposed a quota of 1.15 million tonnes on Ukraine earlier this month to prevent what it called dumping on its market.
Ukraine also expects to export to other former Soviet republics. --Yuri Kulikov, Kiev Newsroom +380 44 229 2264
